messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] TV, and all you need to know
messages.messageBody:
<<Probably they were watching something really interesting. If it's
recorded,
they can pause it without missing dialog, or rewind it. It would be a
shame
if books couldn't be closed and picked up later, but they can, and always

have had that "pause" feature. <g>


Sandra>>

This is why I want to get one of the new systems that lets you pause even
live broadcasts. Very cool!

Kris

messages.subject: TV, and all you need to know
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 5/15/02 9:51:09 PM, rambler@planetcomm.net writes:
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 5/15/02 9:51:09 PM, rambler@... writes:

<< once he spotted that TV picture, it was
like there was nothing else in the room. No matter what else happened for
the next five minutes, he would not take his eyes off that screen. >>

That's the way it will be whenever he's learning something new and
fascinating. I hope you don't take away everything he ever gets excited
about because he's not paying attention to you for that time.

Someday he won't hear you talk to him because he'll be engrossed in a game or
a book. I hope you don't say "I know all I need to know" and take that thing
away from him for the rest of his life. (Oh. You only have the rest of his
childhood. He'll make his own decisions for most of his life.)

<<I have since noticed this in other children when at friends' houses -- the
kids barely even acknowledge that you're there, they can't take their eyes
off the screen, and basically seem hypnotized.>>

Probably they were watching something really interesting. If it's recorded,
they can pause it without missing dialog, or rewind it. It would be a shame
if books couldn't be closed and picked up later, but they can, and always
have had that "pause" feature. <g>


Sandra
